ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Re: Please Help!  How come links extracted fromthis page were not followed/crawled?
ygData.msgSnippet: The default scope rules use the seeds to determine what is and is not in scope. Essentially, if you provide a seed like...

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Re: Please Help!  How come links extracted
 fromthis page were not followed/crawled?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=BEQvOAJ4WBPEs3jHThPprLwL2Qp2o_cTsjo3hvDTFbPT
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

The default scope rules use the seeds to determine what is and is not in 
scope. Essentially, if you provide a seed like...

http://vis.cs.ucdavis.edu/~yuho/homepage/aboutme/aboutme.htm

...then in the absence of other directives, it will consider URIs that 
begin...

http://vis.cs.ucdavis.edu/~yuho/homepage/aboutme/

...as being "in scope".

Behind the scenes, it turns your URI into a "SURT form", then chops off 
the path segment after the last '/', and accepts other URIs whose SURT 
form shares the same prefix.

For more details, see:

http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manual/config.html#surtprefixscope

(The current default configuration uses a SurtPrefixedDecideRule in a 
DecideRule chain, rather than a SurtPrefixScope, but the analysis for 
ruling URIs in is the same as described in the above section of the user
manual.)

- Gordon @ IA

pchoy wrote:
> O.K.  I turned on finer logging and it shows LinksScoper consider 
> those links are out of scope. So my question is, why? 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "pchoy" <philipchoy@...> 
> wrote:
>> I am very puzzled by this.  There are links (<A href=...>) in the
>> following page that are pretty straight forward:
>>
>> http://vis.cs.ucdavis.edu/~yuho/homepage/aboutme/aboutme.htm
>>
>> I am pretty sure links were extracted from this page (I had tried 
>> using
>> ExtractorHTML and JerichoExtractorHTML and my own implementation)...
>> I am using the default job profile so I expected the crawler will 
>> follow all the links found. For example, in the page there is:
>>
>> <a href="../publications/paper/hpc06.pdf" target="_blank">[PDF]</a>
>>
>> If I use http://vis.cs.ucdavis.edu/~yuho/homepage/publications/paper
>> as seed, then I can retrieve the pdf file without problem.
>>
>> At first I thought maybe it's because links were using relative 
> path.
>> But then there are a few links that are not. 
>>
>> Is there something special about this page or I need to change 
>> something in the crawler settings?  There is nothing mentioned in 
> the 
>> logs and reports.
>>
> 
> 
> 
>
